title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [13–18 may 1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [13–18 May 1868]
text: My dear Walti received your letter and money and the chigacagoChicago news all safe and sound on tuesdayTuesday i suppose you see in the papers of the suspension of roberts the postmaster his being short in his returns i believe is the cause of his suspension it seems hard to get honest people in the post offices the very place of all others that ought to be honest men but i have been very luckeylucky lately have not lost any letter or money since the 5) sometimes i think they must have wrote to me from st lous and the letter has been taken but i dontdon't know that they have written to me i have sent two letters to matty since i have got any from her mr Lane received one from Jeff last week i believbelieve it was saying he was just about leaving for kentuckyKentucky but i suppose he is home long before this) i must write to han again so as to stir up mr Heyde see if i get any more of his inteligentintelligent letters i should think it was almost time he blowed off again) well walt you washingtonians aintain't settled the president question yet i wish it was settled one way or the other Edd came up stairs yesterday towards evening before the eagle came the eagle came down stairs and the man i think is a democrat he said to Edd the radicals were all down or something to that affecteffect so eddy came up like mad saying they had cleared the buggers and he would never have any thing more to doodo withe them i how doodo you know he is clear he said it was in the eagle that it would be better to have no congress at all than to doodo as they had it was quite amusing to see eddy is such a gale but when i got the paper i see how things were) well walt its storming again i suppose georgey will be home the poor man has to looselose time but those that gets the most wages their time goes on george hasenthasn't been very well it is kind of bad work not reallreal work but it has been so wet and he has to get down in the pit to see to the cementing and he gets all mud sometimes and he dontdon't favor himself much) well walter dear my paper is small i have plenty of paper but i thought i hadenthadn't much to write about this time so i wouldentwouldn't take a whole sheet i dontdon't get over my lameneslameness yet but i make out to doodo around what has got to be done) mrs glover at east brooklynBrooklyngood bie walter deari have since i wrote this letter got one from Jeff and one from Matty Jeff sent me a letter on the 28th on his return home with 10 dollars which i have never received and the letter man says i never will get it now he had a letter with him and read it to me that jeff had sent to the post office he said it made him feel very bad as it was on his routroute but if the letter ever came to the brooklynBrooklyn post office it was taken before it came to him i think it is too bad i dontdon't think but what the carrier is perfectly honest he has carried letters for 10 years) he said to daytoday their is lots of theivingthieving somewhere he said if my son to st louisSt. Louis had sent a money order he would have got it for me with my signing my name i am very sorry i didentdidn't tell jeff to not send it in a letter he said he should send me some money when he returned i cantcan't get it without any from the post office i wish they could have took it from somebody that didentdidn't want a new dress it was to get mamma a new gown never mind it might have been worse but its very provoking Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [13–18 May 1868]
